Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Silicon-compatible, Crystallographic Oriented Epitaxial Germanium for New Generation of Metal-oxide Semiconductor Field-effect Transistors

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objectives: The objectives of this research program is design, materials synthesis and device based co-exploration of lattice-engineered, crystallographic oriented epitaxial (100), (110) and (111) germanium (Ge) based transistors using large bandgap barrier materials. The approach is a) experimental investigation of p-channel (110)Ge and n-channel (111)Ge quantum well transistors, b) experimental investigation of high hole mobility using (110)Ge and high electron mobility using (111)Ge surface orientation, and c) silicon compatible process flow of biaxially strained Ge transistors.
Intellectual merit: The key scientific merits of this proposal are: i) in-situ growth of Ge transistor structure; ii) tailor-made surface orientations of Ge enable to achieve both high-hole and high-electron mobilities; iii) biaxially strained Ge quantum well transistor using large bandgap materials to enhance hole mobility, iv) larger valence band-offsets for carrier confinement and prevents carrier spill-off, v) elimination of parallel conduction, and vi) enhancement mode transistor operation. Our approaches are most innovative and transformative of in-situ grown epitaxial surface oriented Ge with large bandgap buffers that has a capacity to bring new technologies.
Broader Impact: The proposed Ge research seeks to increase the speed of transistor and substantially reduce power consumption in integrated circuits. Ultra-low power and high-speed computation will benefit applications for industrial, medical, commercial and personal use. The proposed research is interdisciplinary in nature. Through collaboration with industry, we envision direct transfer of device prototypes, to open new avenues for commercialization. The project will train graduate and undergraduate students in the area of nano-scale material science, device physics, and semiconductor fabrication

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has developed materials synthesis and devices based on the low bandgap semiconductor, germanium (Ge). The surface lattice constant of Ge was exploited to achieve different carrier mobility that enable ultra-low power devices that can be integrated with current microprocessor technology. Ultra-low power and high-speed computation will benefit applications for industrial, medical, commercial and personal use. In addition, new transistor architecture based on Ge can outperform with the current low power technology and will enable future implantable medical devices and ubiquitous embedded computing (internet-of-things). Also, Ge based light emitters and detectors monolithically integrated with state-of-the-art logic technology can handle large data rates enabling more powerful distributed computing and faster communication. All of these findings paved the way towards energy efficient "green electronics" that required lower power and can longer usage for mobile applications.

The research is first of its kind to comprehensively investigate the multiple applications of Ge based materials and device structures from computing-to-heath care-to-communication. As a result of this work, we have developed an international collaboration to further explore and refine our initial research focus. Novel ultra-low power Ge based transistor architecture that are predicted to outperform current state-of-the-art technology. The findings from this work have also incorporated into curriculum development and disseminated to undergraduate students to inspire and encourage their interest in STEM related fields, in particular microelectronics and optoelectronics.
